citeinfo.title: Plant and Animal Phenology Data for the United States

descript.abstract: As of January 1, 2013, the dataset contains phenology data on 591 species of plants and animals, with 7,512 locations registered across the United States. Protocols used are documented in Denny et. al., Submitted (contact nco@usanpn.org for more information). Data were collected using the phenophase status approach (Thomas et. al., 2010; Denny et. al. Submitted). Latitude and longitude given in WGS84 Datum. This is a suite of yearly data sets (Plants beginning in 2009, Animals beginning in 2010) each provided with and without full phenophase definitions.
descript.purpose: In response to the growing need to understand the response of plant and animal species to environmental variation and climate change and to develop a widespread baseline against which future phenological change may be measured, a consortium of scientists and agencies organized the USA-NPN, with a mandate to collect and share phenology data. More information on the USA-NPN can be found at http://www.usanpn.org/about.
descript.supplinf: Denny, E.G., K.L. Gerst, A.J. Miller-Rushing, G.L. Tierney, T.M. Crimmins, C.A.F. Enquist, P. Guertin, A.H. Rosemartin, M.D. Schwartz, K.A. Thomas and J.F. Weltzin. Submitted. Standardized phenology monitoring methods to track plant and animal activity for science and resource management applications. and Thomas, K.A., E.G. Denny, A.J. Miller-Rushing, T.M. Crimmins, and J.F. Weltzin. 2010. The National Phenology Monitoring System v0.1. USA-NPN Technical Series 2010-001. www.usanpn.org.

theme.themekey: Plants, Animals, Ground stations, Migratory routes/rates, Species life history, Biosphere, Biota

idinfo.useconst: The USA-NPN National Coordinating Office (nco@usanpn.org), referred to as "USA-NPN," requires that all downloaded USA-NPN data and/or other forms of information from the USA-NPN Website by a user, referred to as "User," be acknowledged as received from the USA-NPN according to the following terms of this USA-NPN Data Attribution Policy. 1. The following acknowledgement must be included in either the main text or Acknowledgments section of all publications using USA-NPN data. Acknowledgment: Data were provided by the USA National Phenology Network and the many participants who contribute to its Nature's Notebook program." 2. Bibliographic information must be provided to the USA-NPN National Coordinating Office (nco@usanpn.org) for all manuscripts using USA-NPN data immediately after their publication. 3. All USA-NPN data sets should be cited following the example below. Citation: USA National Phenology Network. 2010. Plant Phenology Data for the United States, 2009. Tucson, Arizona, USA: USA-NPN. Data set accessed YYYY-MM-DD at http://www.usanpn.org/results/data.

enttyp.enttypd: Each record gives the status of a phenophase for given species (for animals) or individual organism (plants), phenophase, location and day.
enttyp.enttypds: Denny, E.G., K.L. Gerst, A.J. Miller-Rushing, G.L. Tierney, T.M. Crimmins, C.A.F. Enquist, P. Guertin, A.H. Rosemartin, M.D. Schwartz, K.A. Thomas and J.F. Weltzin. Submitted. Standardized phenology monitoring methods to track plant and animal activity for science and resource management applications.

attr.attrdef: The unique identifier for each record in this data set, and the primary key in the observation table of the National Phenology Database.
The unique identifier for the station at which the observation was recorded.
The date the observation was made.
The unique identifier for the plant of animal species for which the observation is about.
The scientific name of the species observed.
The common name of the species observed.
The taxonomic kingdom of the organism for which the observation is about.
The pheonphase type (for plants: leaf, flower, fruit and for animals: activity, reproduction, development, method)
The full definition for each phenophase, what behaviors or attributes of each species indicate the phenophase is occurring.
Further information on the phenophase presented to the observer for the particular species.
The yes, no or uncertain value for a phenophase.

edom.edomvd: No, the phenophase is not occurring.
The observer did not check for the phenophase, or was unable to conclusively identify the species or phenophase.

attr.attrdef: The latitude of the observation location (site).
The longitude of the observation location (site).
The elevation, in feet, of the observation location (from USGS web service, or free entered by the user).
The name of the network, or partner organization to which the observer belongs.

edom.edomvd: Default value for participants coming through to the data entry page directly through the USA-NPN interface.

cntorgp.cntorg: USA National Phenology Network's National Coordinating Office

distinfo.distliab: While substantial efforts are made to ensure the accuracy of USA-NPN data and documentation contained in a data set, complete accuracy of data and metadata cannot be guaranteed. All USA-NPN data and metadata are made available "as is." Users of USA-NPN data hold all parties involved in the production and distribution of a data set harmless for damages resulting from its use or interpretation.

metainfo.metstdn: FGDC Content Standards for Digital Geospatial Metadata
